awd_titl_txt: Pacific Decadal Variability: Modulation of Global- to Regional-scale Climate over the Last Millennium
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use climate model simulations to assist the paleoclimate community with the interpretation of ice core records and provide a valuable, basin-wide paleo history of Pacific climate variability which will be made available to the broader scientific community. Results from this work are expected to reveal how the interactive effects between the underlying background state of the Pacific and individual El Niño/La Niña events have changed over the longer context of Earth's climate history. Thus, enhanced knowledge of Pacific decadal variability and its historical effects on both global and regional climate will help guide precautionary efforts taken to ameliorate their anticipated economic and societal impacts in the future. This team of researchers continuously and consistently disseminate their research results through the Education and Outreach Program at The Ohio State University's Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center, dedicated to providing climate information to students, the public and policymakers at all levels. In addition, this project provides support, training, and mentoring for a female postdoctoral researcher representing the next generation of the scientists in this field.

Pacific Ocean surface temperatures oscillate between warm and cold phases every few decades, and these multi-decadal shifts in the background state of the Pacific Ocean affect both regional and global climate. On the regional scale, the underlying warm or cold background state of the Pacific Ocean modulates how individual El Niño/La Niña events affect temperature and precipitation in specific areas. To better predict the impacts of El Niño events on global climate, it is essential to know the background state of the Pacific Ocean. However, our current understanding of this behavior is limited due to relatively short modern instrument observational records. Thus, other methods, such as modeling and/or the use of paleoclimate proxy data, are often used to define Pacific Ocean temperatures prior to the instrumental period. The key goal of this project is to establish a history of Pacific decadal variability and its global climatic influences for the past millennium using a combination of global climate model simulations and readily available ice core records from four different regions around the Pacific Basin. Each ice core provides records of local to global scale climate primarily through annual layer thicknesses (accumulation), stable water isotopic ratios (temperature), and concentrations of both insoluble dust and major anions and cations (atmospheric chemistry). Each record provides distinct insights on precipitation and temperature which will be used to reconstruct the history of basin-wide Pacific variability. The model simulations will serve to improve interpretation of the ice core data and advancing the understanding of underlying mechanisms driving the observed ice core responses to Pacific climate variability. The use of the ice core records also helps evaluate and possibly enhance model capabilities to physically represent critical processes responsible for local climate variability across the Pacific.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Climate variability in the Pacific Ocean affects climate and weather across the globe. The multi-decadal component of this variability is poorly understood given the relatively short observational records. Previous studies have sought to understand the history of Pacific climate variability using various paleo-proxy records, including corals, ocean sediment cores, tree rings, and ice cores. However, many of these studies rely on proxy records from one region and are thus limited in their geographic scope. Obtaining a basin-wide history of multi-decadal Pacific climate variability provides better knowledge of its global impacts in time periods dominated by natural forcings and those dominated by human-induced climate changes.

The primary objective of this project involved the reconstruction of multi-decadal Pacific climate variability using four ice cores previously retrieved from glaciers or ice caps in southeast Alaska, the Tibetan Plateau, the Andes of southern Peru, and on the Antarctic Peninsula. This reconstruction is one of the first basin-wide histories of Pacific climate variability covering the last ~550 years and provides year-to-year variability of this complex system. Comparisons between our reconstruction and other observed and reconstructed indices of Pacific climate variability show many similarities, but also reveal some key differences. Our reconstruction compares well with those developed using several paleo-proxy assimilation products which incorporate thousands of paleo-records and therefore demonstrates the power and potential of the Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center's global collection of ice core records.

In addition, the ice core-derived reconstruction suggests that the Little Ice Age (~1400-1850 CE) was characterized by more La Niña-like conditions. Our results also show that the sea surface temperature gradient between the eastern and western Pacific, as well as the latitudinal range of the Intertropical Convergence Zone, are both strongly related to multidecadal Pacific climate variability, but only in the current era (post-1850 CE). During the Little Ice Age, external factors, such as solar or volcanic forcing, may have played a stronger role in Pacific climate variability. 

A further goal of this project entails teasing out local and regional variability by removing the background influence of multi-decadal Pacific climate variability defined by our reconstruction. In doing so, we hope to better define local to regional-scale climate variability signals preserved in the four ice core records. Preliminary results support our hypothesis and also reveal non-linearities in the response to local climate variability. Data analysis on this aspect of the project is ongoing. Furthermore, global circulation model simulations using the Community Atmosphere Model (CAM6) were conducted, including over 700 years of diverse El Niño-Southern Oscillation conditions to explore the interactive effects between multi-decadal and interannual climate variability in the Pacific Ocean Basin. All simulations are complete and data analyses are ongoing.

A female postdoctoral researcher received vital mentoring in project management, experimental design, and data analysis and is now employed as a faculty member at another institution. She is the first author of one publication in Journal of Climate and has two other first-authored manuscripts in preparation. The results from this project have been presented at the annual meetings of the American Geophysical Union and the American Meteorological Society, and in an invited seminar entitled "Time after time: Contextualizing recent climatic changes using natural archives of Earth's climate history" at the Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies, Millbrook, N.Y. The postdoctoral researcher co-convened an American Geophysical Union meeting session related to this project on Sub-Decadal Ocean-Atmosphere Variability: Insights from Proxies, Models, and Uncertainty Examinations and led the Unlearning Racism in Geosciences pod at The Ohio State University. The four investigators involved in this project continually provide scientific information to policymakers, the public, and students at all levels. Examples illustrating the breadth of the outlets where project team members have presented their research include the Annual Meeting of the Association of Science Writers (2021); Great Lakes Bootcamp (2021); Sigma Xi Annual Lecture at Villanova University (2021); The Ohio State University Alumni Club (2020); The Monday Talks for the general public in Newark, Ohio (2019). The investigators are also working with a children's book author to create a picture book on ice core science.
